citations.narrative:
On September 20, 2025, “Rico” the approximately 3-year-old male sloth was interacting with the public for 6 hours without
opportunity to rest out of public eye.
From 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM, Rico participated in a public presentation and public interaction (petting) with photo
opportunities. Rico was a popular attraction and the inspector observed intermittent long lines. Rico hung from a railing or
rested on a chair. Rico was observed crawling down the railing and spending time on the ground under the chair, but still
within public view. His handler was observed picking him back up and returning him to the railing periodically (the
inspector observed this twice in the 30 minute interval of direct observation).
When asked about a break period, facility representatives stated Rico would not have a scheduled break during this
event. If staff believed Rico to be asleep based on him closing his eyes, petting was not allowed, but other guest
interactions continued (such as approaching and taking photographs).
Six hours is the majority of a sloth’s waking hours. Sloths in captivity sleep an average of 14 - 20 hours a day and are
often motionless even when awake. Extended periods of time in constant view of the public increase the risk of stress and
abnormal behavior. Increased activity levels and crawling under a chair suggest that Rico was searching for a place to
retreat out of the public eye.
The licensee must ensure that animals are exhibited only for periods of time and under conditions consistent with their
good health and well-being.
Correction date: This day forward, September 25, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
